>>27802379
"The grass is always greener on the other side" anon. It's a falacious argument born from a mentality that only considers your own perspective and experience. For everyone you can point to that you perceive has better than you, has more than you, they too have their own unique circumstances, life history, problems, and are also looking at another's situation, pining to have what they have. The truth is that there is no easy experience of life. There is no hidden formula to happiness, no guarantees of contentment, only opportunities to learn and fail and do better next time. Trying is what makes a triumph; victory and success cannot be handed to you, and especially not happiness or fulfillment, they are earned and given meaning through the endurance of trials and overcoming of challenges. What you must want for yourself is not the end result of such experiences, but the strength to embark on them, the courage to endure them, and the wisdom to learn from them. What carries value is not the reward, but the lessons you learn from the attempt. That is the real prize, and, again, nobody can give it to you. I promise you, that if you challenge yourself, give yourself opportunity, have empathy for yourself and others, and simply try as hard as you can as often as you can to elevate yourself and your circumstances, the bounty you earn from the effort you put in will feel like a Kingdom's treasure, regardless of its value as perceived by others. That is the true mark of success, and it's wholly within your power to attain it. You must not envy those who have more, but learn from them, consider them as humans such as yourself, with only circumstance and effort marking the differences between you and them. Chad doesn't envy others who have more, not because he has it all, but because he has what he has by having earned it through will alone, and knows that this is what is truly worthwhile in life.

>still in love with my high school oneitis
how do I get over her? At this point, she is a fictional character I have created in my mind, since we have literally never spoken to each other and she does not know i exist

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
It's to do with the psychology of the 'first love' and how that tends to be a foundational aspect of your perceptions of the world.

You need to accept that she was your 'first love', and that your brain is sort of tricking you or in a loop that is unrealistic and actually untrue. She may never go out of your head (altho youll dwell on her less and youll even forget how certain memories actually were), but you have the ability to look at those thoughts and observe them and say "why am i having these thoughts?".

Also, if you have these unshaking negative thoughts when youre in bed, then get out of bed immediately, open the curtains or turn on the lights to get some light, and have a shower which is cold at the end of it. Youre thoughts will shift to a positive frame thru this. Thats from my experience too so you know its true.

threads.com:
tl;dr I’m an investment banker in London, considering taking a massive pay cut and joining the police.

I was a uniformed officer for around 18 months in my home town and I was pretty good at it. We owned investigations into volume crime such as thefts, basic assaults and drug offences, etc.

I loved the investigatory side, building cases, interviewing people.

However, I decided I wanted a degree so went to uni and studied finance. I lucked my way into a consulting firm for a couple years then transitioned to an investment bank.

I’m earning great money - currently on £65k, aged 27. Money would be even better if I’d joined earlier like most people. I can work from home any day I want, the office is great, and the work really isn’t that hard - most days I’ll do 9ish hours, some of which is spent wasting time. It’s better hours than the police and progression will be faster. The job is a ticket to a better quality of life than I thought possible - house, cars, holidays, so on.

But I miss being in the police. All of my intelligence and creativity is being used, ultimately, to make rich people richer. In exchange I get a small cut of the pie. Meanwhile, I know for a fact that children out there are being abused by organised criminal groups every week. I feel like spending my life and abilities in the accumulation of wealth is a meaningless and shallow existence, when I could be using it to prevent evil acts.

I applied to the met police’s direct entry detective programme, and have an offer. It’s the one for graduates, with supposedly accelerated promotion.

Pay cut would be about £30k. Not allowed to work from home. Irregular hours. Slower progression. Risk of danger. Certainly less ‘respect’ and admiration that my current role. By the standards of the world, I’d be going down a few notches. But I want it anyway. I feel called to it. Is it worth pursuing? Or am I having a midlife crisis?
